Arrhythmia Visualization

Back To Projects
Watch Raw Data On YouTube
Research Paper Published On Top Journal

Introduction

Optical imaging with voltage-sensitive dyes is the state-of-art technique for electrophysiological mapping of the heart, which has helped to enhance our understanding of complex arrhythmias, as well as our knowledge of electrophysiological remodeling in gene-editing states. Our system uses a 100X100 pixel complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) camera that can achieve acquisition rates of up to 10,000 frames/s. Data from this system are saved as a series of 100X100 matrixes, each acquired at a specific time point. Each pixel represents a measure of fluorescent intensity collected from a specific location on the tissue preparation at a specific time.

Implementation

Data were acquired at 1 kHz by the Cardioplex (Redshirt Imaging) and analyzed using a custom R script and visualized by R/OriginLab.

Highlight

Explore data with R.
Visualize data with R.
Practical problem transformation.
Mathematical solution to time-scaled matrices.

Achievement

The analysis method and visualization pattern I built up were used in many projects. One of the paper was published on JACC, with impact factor of 19.896, ranking 1st in cardiology filed.
